description: From Latin ferruminatus, p.p. of ferruminare (“to cement, solder”), from ferrumen (“cement”), from ferrum (“iron”).

verbs.description: ferruminate (third-person singular simple present ferruminates, present participle ferruminating, simple past and past participle ferruminated)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To solder or unite, as for example metals.
examples: too many other passages ferruminated by Jonson from Seneca's tragedies and the writings of the later Romans
